title: Metal-Acid Reactions
subject: integrated-science
description: Investigate how different metals react with dilute hydrochloric acid and learn the reactivity series
materials: Test tubes and test tube rack
Small pieces of: Magnesium ribbon, Zinc granules, Iron filings, Copper turnings
objectives: Observe and compare the reactions of different metals with acid
Identify which metals react with dilute hydrochloric acid
Recognize hydrogen gas production through bubbling
Arrange metals in order of reactivity
Explain the reactivity series and its importance

theory.introduction: When reactive metals are placed in dilute acids, they displace hydrogen from the acid, producing a salt and hydrogen gas. The speed of this reaction depends on the metal's position in the reactivity series.

reactivitySeries.description: The reactivity series ranks metals from most reactive to least reactive

order.reactivity: Most reactive - reacts violently with water and acids
Very reactive - reacts vigorously with water and acids
Moderately reactive - steady reaction with acids
Slowly reactive - gradual reaction with acids
Least reactive - does not react with acids

reactivitySeries.rule: Only metals above hydrogen in the series can displace hydrogen from acids

observations.fastReaction: Vigorous bubbling, heat production, metal dissolves quickly
observations.slowReaction: Occasional bubbles, little or no heat, metal dissolves slowly
observations.noReaction: No bubbles, no heat, metal remains unchanged

procedure.instruction: Put on safety goggles and protective gloves
procedure.safety: CRITICAL - Acids can cause burns and eye damage

procedure.instruction: Label 4 test tubes: A (Magnesium), B (Zinc), C (Iron), D (Copper)
procedure.note: Keep test tubes in a rack on a stable surface

procedure.instruction: Add about 5 mL of dilute hydrochloric acid to each test tube
Add a small piece of magnesium ribbon to test tube A
Observe and record the reaction rate, bubbling, and temperature change
procedure.expected: Very fast reaction, lots of bubbles, tube feels warm

procedure.instruction: Add zinc granules to test tube B

procedure.expected: Moderate reaction, continuous bubbles, slight warmth

procedure.instruction: Add iron filings to test tube C
Add copper turnings to test tube D
procedure.observation: Watch for any sign of reaction

procedure.expected: No reaction, no bubbles, copper remains shiny

procedure.instruction: Test for hydrogen gas: Light a splint and bring it near the mouth of tube A
procedure.expected: Hear a 'pop' sound - confirms hydrogen gas
procedure.safety: Keep face away from test tube opening

procedure.instruction: Wait 5 minutes and compare all four tubes

copper.explanation: Copper is below hydrogen in the reactivity series and cannot displace it from acids

analysis.hydrogenTest: The 'pop' sound confirms hydrogen gas production. Hydrogen is flammable and burns with oxygen in air to produce the characteristic sound.
analysis.exothermicReactions: Faster reactions release more heat energy. This indicates the reaction is exothermic.
analysis.displacement: Only metals more reactive than hydrogen can displace it from acids. This is why copper does not react.

applications.description: Copper and stainless steel cookware are safe because they don't react with acidic foods like tomatoes or lemon juice.
Zinc is used in many batteries because of its moderate reactivity. It provides electrons through chemical reactions.
Iron is coated with zinc to prevent rusting. The zinc reacts instead of the iron, providing sacrificial protection.
Magnesium hydroxide and other metal compounds are used in antacids to neutralize excess stomach acid.
Understanding reactivity helps predict how much energy is needed to extract metals from their ores. More reactive metals require more energy.
Gold and silver are used for jewelry because they don't react with acids, sweat, or air, maintaining their appearance.
Bronze (copper alloy) is used for outdoor statues because it resists corrosion better than more reactive metals.

safety: ALWAYS wear safety goggles - acids can cause permanent eye damage
Wear protective gloves when handling acids
Work in a well-ventilated area - hydrogen gas is produced
Never add water to concentrated acid - always add acid to water
If acid spills on skin, rinse immediately with plenty of water for at least 10 minutes
Keep long hair tied back and loose clothing secured
Hydrogen gas is flammable - test carefully with a lit splint
Keep face and body away from test tube openings
Never taste or smell chemicals directly
Dispose of chemical waste properly as instructed by teacher
Wash hands thoroughly after the experiment

extendedLearning.displacementReactions: A more reactive metal can displace a less reactive metal from its salt solution. For example, zinc can displace copper from copper sulfate solution: Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu
extendedLearning.electrochemicalSeries: The reactivity series is related to standard electrode potentials. More reactive metals have more negative potentials and lose electrons more easily.
extendedLearning.thermodynamics: The reactivity series reflects the stability of metal ions. More reactive metals form more stable ions and release more energy when reacting.
extendedLearning.industrialImportance: Understanding metal reactivity is crucial for: metal extraction (pyrometallurgy and hydrometallurgy), corrosion prevention, alloy design, and battery technology.

A reaction where a more reactive element replaces a less reactive element in a compound

A reaction that releases heat energy to the surroundings
An ionic compound formed when a metal reacts with an acid
An acid solution that contains a relatively small amount of acid dissolved in water
A fast, energetic reaction with lots of bubbling and heat production
